Award.AbstractNarration:
Under the terms of this grant, the Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics (SIAM) will administer a travel award program for approximately 100 U. S. mathematical and computational scientists, particularly early career faculty and graduate students to attend the International Congress on Industrial and Applied Mathematics (ICIAM 2015), to be held on August 10-14, 2015 in Beijing, China. The ICIAM congresses are held every four years and are the primary worldwide forum for presentation of advances in the mathematical and computational sciences and their applications to science and technology.

Travel awards are especially important for early career researchers and graduate students who may otherwise have difficulty in marshalling sufficient funds. Without travel support, they would be likely to take less advantage of this opportunity for direct interaction and networking on an international scale. This support will help U.S. mathematical and computational scientists keep pace with the advances in applications to technology and science being developed throughout the world. The award process will acknowledge the importance of diversity, encourage women and minorities to apply, and give priority to qualified applicants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this grant from the NSF DMS Infrastructure Program was to fund travel for participants in the Eighth International Congress on Industrial and Applied Mathematics held in Beijing, on August 10-14, 2015 (ICIAM15). ICIAM 2015 is the eighth quadrennial International Congress on Industrial and Applied Mathematics. It is a worldwide congress for industrial and applied mathematics, with prestige comparable to the International Congress of Mathematicians. Travel awards were designed to (partially) cover air transportation, lodging, and registration costs consistent with the rules and procedures of the National Science Foundation.  A second goal of this grant is to help ensure sufficient participation of US researchers in this international congress.

 

SIAM established a website for travel applications to ICIAM15. There were 132 applications from across the U.S., including 37 graduate students, 69 post-doctoral/early career researchers and 26 senior researchers. To evaluate the applicants and award the travel grants, we assembled three teams of three reviewers, each of which  were assigned to review the application documents (a letter of application, a recent CV, and a letter of recommendation) of one third of the  applicants. The applicants were ranked by average score. We awarded 100 travel grants, 10 travel grants to minority applicants (63%), 27 grants to women (73%) and 29 grants to students (76%). The awardees came from 28 States and 65 Institutions in the United States.

 

In our post ICIAM15 survey of the individuals who were supported under this grant, we found that the reputation of ICIAM and its wide variety of minisymposia were the two strongest draws. In addition, 87% agreed with the statement that the technical program was excellent, 95% agreed that they acquired information that was helpful for their research.

 ICIAM15 proved to be an ideal venue for interaction of U.S. attendees with the broader world-wide community of researchers in applied and computational mathematics. It provided the opportunity to engage other researchers in emerging areas of research and applications. This was especially important for graduate students and early career researchers, since it provided them with the ability to hear the latest research from around the world in areas they are working in and, perhaps even more importantly, establish contacts with researchers that they might not be able to meet in other circumstances.

In our post-ICIAM15 survey, 89% of those supported by this grant agreed that they were able to make contacts with researchers that they would never have met otherwise. Moreover, more than 95% acknowledged that the support from this grant was essential or important to their being able to attend.
